factoid: Natásha interrupted Nicholas.
Natásha remembered being punished once about some plums.
Nicholas and the others were dancing.
Natásha sat sobbing in the schoolroom.
Natásha felt sad and sorry for everyone, for herself, and for everyone.
Natásha was innocent.
Nicholas remembered the punishment event.
Nicholas came to Natásha afterwards and wanted to comfort her.
Nicholas felt ashamed.
Nicholas had a funny doll and wanted to give it to Natásha.
Uncle called Natásha, Nicholas, and Sónya into the study in the old house.
The study was dark.
A Negro stood in the study.
The Negro was gray.
The Negro had white teeth.
The Negro stood and looked at Natásha, Nicholas, and Sónya.
Nicholas said there was a Negro.
Nicholas was uncertain whether the Negro existed, was a dream, or was told about.
Sónya answered that she remembered something too.
Natásha asked Papa and Mamma about the Negro.
Papa and Mamma said there was no Negro.
Sónya remembered the Negro's teeth.
Sónya thought the memory was strange and like a dream.
Sónya liked that memory.
They rolled hard‑boiled eggs in the ballroom.
Two old women spun around on the carpet.
They wondered if the egg‑rolling was real.
They remembered the fun of rolling eggs.
They remembered Papa in a blue overcoat firing a gun in the porch.
They smiled with pleasure while recalling memories.
They laughed with quiet enjoyment.
They recalled poetic youthful memories.
They recalled that dreams and realities blend.
Sónya did not keep pace with them.
They shared the same reminiscences.
Sónya forgot many memories.
Sónya's recollections did not arouse the same poetic feeling as others.
Sónya enjoyed their pleasure.
Sónya tried to fit in with their pleasure.
Sónya only took part when they recalled her first arrival.
Sónya told them she was afraid of Nicholas.
Nicholas had a corded jacket.
Sónya's nurse told her that she would be sewn up with cords.
Natásha remembered being told that she had been born under a cabbage.
Natásha did not disbelieve the cabbage birth story at that time.
Natásha knew the cabbage birth story was not true.
Natásha felt uncomfortable about the cabbage birth story.
A maid thrust her head in at the other door of the sitting room.
The maid whispered that they had brought a cock, Miss.
Natásha replied that the cock was not wanted.
Natásha told Pólya to tell them to take the cock away.
Dimmler entered the sitting room.
Dimmler went up to the harp in the corner.
Dimmler removed the harp's cloth covering.
The harp made a jarring sound.
The old countess asked Dimmler to play her favorite nocturne by Field.
Dimmler struck a chord.
Dimmler remarked that Natásha, Nicholas, and Sónya were quiet.
Natásha said they were philosophizing.
They were discussing dreams.
Dimmler began to play.
Natásha tiptoed noiselessly to the table.
Natásha took up a candle.
Natásha carried the candle out.
Natásha returned to the table.
Natásha seated herself quietly in her former place.
The room was dark where they sat on the sofa.
The full moon's silvery light fell on the floor through the big windows.
Dimmler finished the piece.
Dimmler sat softly running his fingers over the strings.
Dimmler was uncertain whether to stop or play something else.
